Award.AwardTitle: A Laboratory Study of the Problematic Relations between Olfactory Experiences and Language

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

The PI, an expert in science and technology studies, will engage in long-term participant observation at two laboratories of neuroscience and cognitive psychology that study olfaction (the sense of smell). The focus of her study is a well-known argument that olfactory experiences cannot be conveyed by language. She will shed new light on this argument by using laboratory studies to document and communicate the language of olfaction that is used in the context of scientific experimentation. The project will contribute to graduate student training and to broadening participation; the PI has plans to recruit a graduate student research assistant from an underrepresented group. Her research results will be disseminated in a journal article, a book chapter, and an edited volume. They will be used in a methods class for graduate students, and they will be of interest to non-scientists due to their relevance to eating disorders, obesity, and sensory disabilities.

Technical Summary

The PI will use the laboratory studies approach project to provide new insights into one of the central conundrums involved in understanding human olfaction, its relationship with language. It will provide an alternative perspective on the sense of smell as a feature of practical work of science; in doing so, it will turn what is often regarded as illusive and hidden into a material and social feature of action and interaction in the laboratory. The project will draw from ethnomethodology (the study of examines how individuals use everyday conversation and gestures to construct a common-sense view of the world) to engage the sensory aspects of scientific knowing. It will also use insights from the arts, humanities, and other social science approaches to the senses. Its goal is to go beyond the visual-auditory dominance, and treat the sensory as part of the practical doings in the laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Olfactory science, whose object of study is the least understood of the five senses, is experiencing an energetic research period. Concurrently, it is widely accepted that the sense of smell plays a central role in our relationship with the physical and social environment, and that olfaction structures our food intake, memory, awareness of air pollution and has a potential prognostic value in neurodegenerative conditions. The field of Science and Technology Studies (STS) is dedicated to research on the senses and committed to topics such as embodiment, food, materiality, disability and nonhumans, but, in STS, studies of olfactory science are still scarce. While this lack could be due to the widely shared idea that olfaction (together with taste and touch) is a non-dominant sense in humans, it may also concern the peculiarity of the approach that an STS study of olfaction calls for. Building on the latter as its premise, this project follows the tradition of laboratory studies while it explores its outward perimeters so as to broaden the human-oriented tools of social science. In its focus on research on olfactory perception, the project further reflects on how the mode of accounting for experiential and multisensory aspects of science may drive a shift in conceptualizing communication practices and our relationship with the environment.

The project focuses on two cutting-edge scientific laboratories that study olfactory perception: a laboratory of olfactory psychophysics and a laboratory of olfactory neural genetics. Even though the two laboratories are not intended to represent the entire domain of olfactory studies, they are chosen to provide a sense of the contemporary research on olfactory perception that ranges from human experimental psychology to sensory physiology and neuroscience performed on laboratory animals. In the laboratories, the PI conducted participant observations, going beyond what scientists report in publications and interview sessions and capturing the real-time and fine detail of everyday laboratory life. While using audio and video recording to trace intersubjective unfolding of talk, gesture, gaze, prosody, facial expressions, body orientation and aspects of spatial arrangements within the shared world of daily events in the laboratory, the PI also probed and experimented with alternative modes of accounting to get at the particularities of olfactory experiences that are not reducible to visual representations. As a part of this methodological inquiry, the PI worked with two artists. With Evelyn Walker, the PI designed an inhabitable sculpture grounded in the ethnographic observations of olfactory psychophysics, and she realized a soundscape with Andres Gutierrez Martinez to accompany the neural genetics laboratory study. While the two multisensory installations explore how we may communicate ethnographic findings through re-production, re-enactment, and re-experiencing, they also have a pedagogical purpose and were employed in the class that was designed as a part of this project.

Observing how practitioners of olfactory science orient to their subject matter while being experientially immersed in richly scented environments also provided an opportunity for questioning the assumption of olfactory ineffability. In the three journal articles that the PI wrote as part of this project, she considers language as a phenomenon that is enmeshed with the practical, material and interactional elements of laboratory life to indicate how language, rather than representing reality, is a part of that reality. She thus emphasizes aspects of our relationship with the environment that are not only about manipulation but also about immersion, and indicates how language, conventionally taken as a mark of human uniqueness, accentuates our closeness with other animals.
